30 Under 30

30 Under 30 is an exhibition designed to display and encourage the dialogue of 30 artists 30 years of age or younger in the Boston area. This exhibition will present a diversified look at emerging artistic talent in Massachusetts. Discover the voice of the next generation of great artists! Included in this exhibition are 6 artists, chosen to further investigate their point of view through more narrowly focused exhibitions taking place in the winter – so be on the lookout! Participating artists: Emily Abramovich, Joey Asal, Kevin Benisvy, Leah Brunetto, Kelly Burgess, Nabeela Chowdhury, Scott Coffrin, Robyn Day, Cathy Durso, Sean Dunstan-Halliday, Joseph Geary, Olivia Glennon, Amanda Gross, Rachel Hammerman, CJ Heyliger, Helena Hsieh, Vanessa Irzyk, Ariel Kessler, Mary Lydecker, Alison Matthews, Sarah May, Kati Mennett, Evan Morse, Grace Nicklin, Katelyn Paciulan, Bryan Ramey, Katharena Rentumis, Edith Shimel, Wesley Simon, and Sara Zielinski

 

Baba's Village Photo Exhibit

This exhibit of exotic color images and multi-media presentations of a rural Indian village and its inhabitants showcase the deep connection to a man who hasn't lived there in 50 years.

In 2011, Bernardin and her son Jesse traveled with her father-in-law Vinod Tripathi to his native village, Jangoan, in India, in order to document the changes in that corner of the world since their visit 10 year earlier, and to see the girls’ school built by Baba, Vinod Tripathi’s name of endearment in the family.

This is a place so remote that “limitation rather than opportunity defines everyday life,” Bernardin said. “Traveling there” – to a village without electricity or running water – “felt like stepping back in time to an India before outsourcing and call centers and middle-class growth [occurred].”

Her photos capture the luminous landscape, the daily routines, life lived mostly outdoors. Multimedia (video/slide) pieces show the school, interviews with the villagers and Vinod Tripathi, and interactions between the photographer and villagers on the street outside the family home.

This exhibit was made possible with support from the NLT Foundation and the Massachusetts Cultural Council.

Bernardin’s longstanding interest and experience in photography stems from her firm belief in the adage: “every picture tells a story.” Her strength is in capturing the spirit, if not the essence, of people and places – telling stories photographically. Among her previous shows are exhibits at the New Art Center in Newton and the Center for Digital Imaging Arts in Waltham. Bernardin holds a certificate in professional photography from Boston University’s Center for Digital Imaging Arts, where she transitioned from film to digital shooting and printmaking, and honed her lighting and technical skills for commercial work. She also has a Masters Degree in Public Health from the University of North Carolina. She lives in Newton. Her wide-ranging photographic interests may be seen at http://mimibernardinphotography.com/
